answers.q: how much sorbitol in sugar free syrup
answers.a: It varies by product—there’s no standard amount. Sorbitol syrup itself is typically about 70% sorbitol by weight; check the label for sugar alcohols (polyols) per serving, which often total a few grams.

answers.q: how much sorbitol is in sugar-free syrup
answers.a: It depends on the brand and recipe; many sugar-free syrups use sorbitol solution that is about 70% sorbitol. The nutrition label’s sugar alcohols (polyols) per serving shows the amount, often a few to several grams.
It’s an aqueous solution of sorbitol (E420ii) used as a humectant to retain moisture, keep products soft, prevent crystallization, and add mild sweetness and bulk.
As a humectant, sorbitol syrup (E420ii) attracts and holds water in foods, helping maintain softness and freshness while providing mild sweetness and viscosity.

answers.q: which is less sweet corn syrup or sorbitol
answers.a: Regular corn syrup (glucose syrup) is generally less sweet than sorbitol: sorbitol is about 50–60% as sweet as sucrose, while typical corn syrup is roughly 30–50% depending on its DE.
